title: NetworkOnMainThread exception when attempting to send rawlines while connected to a IRC bouncer
label: [Label(name="Bug"), Label(name="Contribution")]
body:
I'm connecting to a [ZNC](http://wiki.znc.in/ZNC) bouncer running on a server somewhere to access some irc networks. 

When I try to do anything that ultimately hits [this method](https://github.com/pocmo/Yaaic/blob/master/pircbot/src/main/java/org/yaaic/protocol/OutputThread.java#L59) (for example, `/nick` or `/join`) nothing happens. 

Debugging a little, an exception is being thrown [here](https://github.com/pocmo/Yaaic/blob/master/pircbot/src/main/java/org/yaaic/protocol/OutputThread.java#L66). The exception stacktrace thrown is included at the bottom. TL;DR it's a NetworkOnMainThreadException.

When I connect to an irc network directly I do not see that exception and can change nick, join channels etc as you'd normally expect. 

What's the difference between connecting to my bouncer and connecting to an IRC network directly? No clue. It might be latency and that going direct is fast enough that it doesn't trigger the exception (though I kinda doubt this as you'd still expect slower connections to see this issue then). From the debugging information I can see that I am on the main thread in both cases when attempting to write to the buffer.

Whatever the reason networking on the main thread is bad. When I wrap that buffer write in something like this everything works as expected when connecting to the bouncer:

```
    Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor().submit(new Runnable() {
        @Override public void run() {
            bwriter.write(line + "\r\n");
            bwriter.flush();   
        }
    });
```

I can submit a fix for this easily enough but I don't want to be naively spinning up threads here there and everywhere. I suspect everything could be put on a background thread a long ways up the line instead of just before writing to the buffer but don't have enough context right now to see where the best place might be. If you have a suggestion I can go about fixing it :) (I will submit a PR soon either way, this bug is really annoying me)

This is also an issue in the version of Yaaic published on the play store.

When updating multiple tables, best practice is to use a transaction to ensure data coherence (also improve the performance).

title: Add support for ~ and & as nickname prefixes
body:
First off, I'd like to note that I did not test these patches, as I was unable to install Eclipse and my generated build.xml did not work. Although these patches are untested, I believe them to be safe to merge. However, please merge with caution if you decide to.

These patches should, assuming I understood your code correctly, help Yaaic correctly recognise ~ and & as nickname prefixes. These are not used by most IRC servers, but there are some that use them. I, for example, am a member of an IRC network which uses ~ for the channel creator. Whenever a channel creator disconnects, Yaaic does not recognise this and leaves said user in the nick list, giving a wrong image on who is online and who is not.

If you are looking for a server using these characters, GeekShed seems to be one, and they have their usage documented [here](http://www.geekshed.net/2009/10/nick-prefixes-explained/).

Thank you for your time and I hope this pull request will be useful for you.

Kind Regards,
TheLastProject

title: Keyboard randomly stops working in the EditText
label: [Label(name="Bug")]
body:
Backstory:  I am in the process of developing an app and was plagued by this issue of the keyboard not sending keystrokes to the EditText (at certain times).  I started digging for other code to see if there was something wrong with mine and ran into Yaaic since it was open source.  Turns out Yaaic has the same issue too (I've tested on a few different devices with different OS's and could reproduce it) - I also noticed comments about it in the Market. 

It seems to be random...but if you type characters, hit enter, then type characters again and do this more than a few times you may see this bug pop up (at least using virtual keyboard, I don't have hardware keyboard).  In my own app, I could not figure out the underlying cause (it might be in the OS), but I did find a workaround that will avert this bug.

For some reason, Android does not like it when executing any other UI code from within the KeyListener/EditorActionListener/onKey (I tried them all).  My solution was to move all of my previous key listening code inside of a Button listener beside my EditText in a horizontal sub-layout.

On the EditText, I set an inputType flag to textShortMessage, which turned that enter key into a smiley key (this way I didn't have any useless keys on the virtual keyboard).  And then just used my new Button as a "Send" key.

Just throwing the idea out there as a workaround.

Ben

title: Wait for authentication before automatic channel joins
label: [Label(name="Bug"), Label(name="Feature")]
body:
There may be other cases where waiting before auto-joining channels would be desirable. But in particular freenode requires me to authenticate with channel services before joining. For this purpose I add to my freenode server config on yaaic:

/msg NickServ identify ********

However there is a delay between sending this message and freenode deciding I am authenticated that prevents me successfully auto-joining channels.

A small delay before auto-joining channels would probably resolve this, but a more robust way would be to wait for a response from chanserv or more service agnostically to continously retry failed channel joins until some expiry or success. The latter approach seems to be what chatzilla does.

Also since this is the inaugural bug, well done on yaaic, it does a lot right and it's nice to see a new project being run so well from the start with github, the site, and the nice logo.

title: Messages are sometimes displayed in the wrong channel/query
label: [Label(name="Bug")]
body:
This happens due to a bug /wrong assumptions in the code updating the DeckView elements. To get the corresponding ListAdapter, first we need to get the ListView from the deck. This is archived by calling getChildAt() with the position provided by the DeckAdapter.

Problem: "The children of the ViewGroup do not correspond 1-to-1 with the items in the list, for a ListView. Instead, the ViewGroup's children correspond to only those views that are visible right now. So getChildAt operates on an index that's internal to the ViewGroup and doesn't necessarily have anything to do with the position in the list that the ListView uses."

title: Conversations order changes
label: [Label(name="Bug")]
body: When resuming the ConversationActivity the conversations are restored by calling values() on the conversations HashMap. This is a bad idea as the order of the Collection returned by values() may change causing the conversations to be shown up in a different order as before.

title: ConcurrentModificationException
label: [Label(name="Bug")]
body:
The LinkedList used in some classes is not synchronized. As these lists may be accessed by more than one thread the iterator will throw ConcurrentModificationExceptions causing the application to "force close".

The relevant parts that access these list have to be synchronized or another list implementation has to be used.

See: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/LinkedList.html
